speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Good afternoon.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Before I go into the details of today’s meeting, I would like to underscore for the American people that we understand the hardship that high inflation is causing and that we are strongly committed to bringing inflation back down to our 2 percent goal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Over the course of the year, we have taken forceful actions to tighten the stance of monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have covered a lot of ground, and the full effects of our rapid tightening so far are yet to be felt.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Even so, we have more work to do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Price stability is the responsibility of the Federal Reserve and serves as the bedrock of our economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Without price stability, the economy doesn’t work for anyone.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In particular, without price stability, we will not achieve a sustained period of strong labor market conditions that benefit all.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Today, the FOMC raised our policy interest rate by ½ percentage point.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We continue to anticipate that ongoing increases will be appropriate in order to attain a stance of monetary policy that is sufficiently restrictive to return inflation to 2 percent over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In addition, we are continuing the process of significantly reducing the size of our balance sheet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Restoring price stability will likely require maintaining a restrictive policy stance for some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I will have more to say about today’s monetary policy actions after briefly reviewing economic developments.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The U.S. economy has slowed significantly from last year’s rapid pace.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Although real GDP rose at a pace of 2.9 percent last quarter, it is roughly unchanged through the first three quarters of this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Recent indicators point to modest growth of spending and production this quarter.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Growth in consumer spending has slowed from last year’s rapid pace, in part reflecting lower real disposable income and tighter financial conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Activity in the housing sector has weakened significantly, largely reflecting higher mortgage rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Higher interest rates and December 14, 2022 slower output growth also appear to be weighing on business fixed investment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As shown in our Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL Summary of Economic Projections, the median projection for real GDP growth stands at just 0.5 percent this year and next, well below the median estimate of the longer-run normal growth rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Despite the slowdown in growth, the labor market remains extremely tight, with the unemployment rate near a 50-year low, job vacancies still very high, and wage growth elevated.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Job gains have been robust, with employment rising by an average of 272,000 jobs per month over the last three months.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Although job vacancies have moved below their highs and the pace of job gains has slowed from earlier in the year, the labor market continues to be out of balance, with demand substantially exceeding the supply of available workers.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The labor force participation rate is little changed since the beginning of the year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: FOMC participants expect supply and demand conditions in the labor market to come into better balance over time, easing upward pressures on wages and prices.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The median projection in the SEP for the unemployment rate rises to 4.6 percent at the end of next year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation remains well above our longer-run goal of 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Over the 12 months ending in October, total PCE prices rose 6 percent; excluding the volatile food and energy categories, core PCE prices rose 5 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In November, the 12-month change in the CPI was 7.1 percent, and the change in the core CPI was 6 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The inflation data received so far for October and November show a welcome reduction in the monthly pace of price increases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But it will take substantially more evidence to give confidence that inflation is on a sustained downward path.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Price pressures remain evident across a broad range of goods and services.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Russia’s war against Ukraine has boosted prices for energy and food and has contributed to upward pressure on inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The median projection in the SEP for total PCE inflation is December 14, 2022 5.6 percent this year and falls to 3.1 percent next year, 2.5 percent in 2024, and 2.1 percent in Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL 2025; participants continue to see risks to inflation as weighted to the upside.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Despite elevated inflation, longer-term inflation expectations appear to remain well anchored, as reflected in a broad range of surveys of households, businesses, and forecasters as well as measures from financial markets.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But that is not grounds for complacency; the longer the current bout of high inflation continues, the greater the chance that expectations of higher inflation will become entrenched.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Fed’s monetary policy actions are guided by our mandate to promote maximum employment and stable prices for the American people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: My colleagues and I are acutely aware that high inflation imposes significant hardship as it erodes purchasing power, especially for those least able to meet the higher costs of essentials like food, housing, and transportation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are highly attentive to the risks that high inflation poses to both sides of our mandate, and we are strongly committed to returning inflation to our 2 percent objective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At today’s meeting, the Committee raised the target range for the federal funds rate by ½ percentage point, bringing the target range to 4¼ to 4½ percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we are continuing the process of significantly reducing the size of our balance sheet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: With today’s action, we have raised interest rates by 4¼ percentage points this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We continue to anticipate that ongoing increases in the target range for the federal funds rate will be appropriate in order to attain a stance of monetary policy that is sufficiently restrictive to return inflation to 2 percent over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Over the course of the year, financial conditions have tightened significantly in response to our policy actions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Financial conditions fluctuate in the short term in response to many factors, but it is important that, over time, they reflect the policy restraint that we are putting in place to return inflation to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are seeing the effects on demand in December 14, 2022 the most interest-sensitive sectors of the economy, such as housing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It will take time, however, Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL for the full effects of monetary restraint to be realized, especially on inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In light of the cumulative tightening of monetary policy and the lags with which monetary policy affects economic activity and inflation, the Committee decided to raise interest rates by 50 basis points today, a step-down from the 75 basis point pace seen over the previous four meetings.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, 50 basis points is still a historically large increase, and we still have some ways to go.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As shown in the SEP, the median projection for the appropriate level of the federal funds rate is 5.1 percent at the end of next year, ½ percentage point higher than projected in September.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The median projection is 4.1 percent at the end of 2024 and 3.1 percent at the end of 2025, still above the median estimate of its longer-run value.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, these projections do not represent a Committee decision or plan, and no one knows with any certainty where the economy will be a year or more from now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our decisions will depend on the totality of incoming data and their implications for the outlook for economic activity and inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we will continue to make our decisions meeting by meeting and communicate our thinking as clearly as possible.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are taking forceful steps to moderate demand so that it comes into better alignment with supply.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our overarching focus is using our tools to bring inflation back down to our 2 percent goal and to keep longer-term inflation expectations well anchored.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Reducing inflation is likely to require a sustained period of below-trend growth and some softening of labor market conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Restoring price stability is essential to set the stage for achieving maximum employment and stable prices over the longer run.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The historical record cautions strongly against prematurely loosening policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We will stay the course until the job is done.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: To conclude: We understand that our actions affect communities, families, and businesses across the country.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Everything we do is in service to our public mission.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We at the December 14, 2022 Fed will do everything we can to achieve our maximum-employment and price-stability goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I will look forward to your questions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, as I mentioned, it is important that overall financial conditions continue to reflect the policy restraint that we’re putting in place to bring inflation down to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We think that financial conditions have tightened significantly in the past year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But our policy actions work through financial conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And those, in turn, affect economic activity, the labor market, and inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So what we control is our policy moves in the communications that we make.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Financial conditions both anticipate, and react to, our actions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would add that our focus is not on short-term moves, but on persistent moves.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And many, many things, of course, move financial conditions over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would say it’s our judgment today that we’re not at a sufficiently restrictive policy stance yet, which is why we say that we would expect that ongoing hikes would be appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I would point you to the SEP again for our current assessment of what that peak level will be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As you will have seen, 19 people filled out the SEP this time, and 17 of those 19 wrote down a peak rate of 5 percent or more—in the 5s.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s our best assessment today for what we think the peak rate will be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You will also know that, at each subsequent SEP during the course of this year, we’ve actually increased our estimate of what that peak rate will be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And today we’re—the SEP that was published shows again that, overwhelmingly, FOMC participants believe that inflation risks are to the upside.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I can’t tell you confidently that we won’t move up our estimate of the peak rate again at the next SEP.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t know what we’ll do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It will depend on future data.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What we’re writing down today is our best estimate of what we think that peak rate will be, based on what we know.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Obviously, if data—if the inflation data come in worse, that could move up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it could move down if inflation data are softer.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, as I’ve been saying, as we’ve gone through the course of this year, as we lifted off and got into the course of the year and we saw the—how strong inflation was and how persistent, it was very important to move quickly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In fact, the speed—the pace with which we’re moving was the most important thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think now that we’re coming to the end of this year, we’ve raised 425 basis points this year, and we’re into restrictive territory.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s now not so important how fast we go.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That will become the most important question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I would say the most important question now is no longer the speed.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So—and that applies to February as well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I December 14, 2022 think we’ll make the February decision based on the incoming data and where we see financial Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL conditions, where we see the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’ll be the key thing, but—I mean, for that decision.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, ultimately, that question about how high to raise rates is going to be one that we make looking at our progress on inflation, looking at where financial conditions are, and making an assessment of whether policy is restrictive enough.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: [As] I’ve told you today, we have an assessment that we’re not at a restrictive enough stance, even with today’s move.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ve laid out our own—our individual assessments of what we would need to do to get there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At a certain point, though, we’ll get to that point.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And there, the strong view on the Committee is that we’ll need to stay there, you know, until we’re really confident that inflation is coming down in a sustained way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we think that that will be some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you look at—you can break inflation down into three, sort of, buckets.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The first is goods inflation, and we see now, as we’ve been expecting, really, for a year and a half, that supply conditions would get better.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, ultimately, supply chains get fixed, and demand settles down a little bit and maybe goes back to services a little bit.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we start to see goods inflation coming down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re now starting to see that in this report and the last one.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Then you go to housing services.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We know the story there is that housing services inflation has been very, very high and will continue to go up, actually.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As rents expire and have to be renewed, they’re going to be renewed into a market where rates are higher than they were when the original leases were signed.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we see that the new leases that are—that the rate for new leases is coming down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, once we work our way through that backlog, that inflation will December 14, 2022 come down sometime next year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The third piece, which is something like 55 percent of the Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL index, PCE core inflation index, is non-housing-related core services.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s really a function of the labor market, largely.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The biggest cost, by far, in that sector is labor.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we do see a very, very strong labor market, one where we haven’t seen much softening, where job growth is very high, where wages are very high.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Vacancies are quite elevated, and, really, there’s an imbalance in the labor market between supply and demand.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that part of it, which is the biggest part, is likely to take a substantial period to get down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The other—you know, the goods inflation has turned pretty quickly now after not turning at all for a year and a half.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now it seems to be turning.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But there’s an expectation, really, that the services inflation will not move down so quickly, so that we’ll have to stay at it, so that we may have to raise rates higher to get to where we want to go.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s really why we are writing down those high rates and why we’re expecting that they’ll have to remain high for a time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, I’ll tell you what the projection is.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t think it would qualify as a recession, though, because you’ve got positive growth.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The expectations in the SEP are basically as you said, which is, we’ve got growth at a modest level, which is to say that December 14, 2022 ½ percentage point, that’s positive growth.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s slow growth.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s well below trend.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s not Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL going to feel like a boom.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In that condition, labor market conditions are softening a bit.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Unemployment does go up a bit.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would say that many analysts believe that the natural rate of unemployment is actually elevated at this moment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s not clear that those forecasts of inflation are really much above the natural rate of unemployment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We can never identify its location with great precision.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But that 4.7 percent is still a strong labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you look—you know, you’ve got—the reports we get from the field are that companies are very reluctant to lay people off, other than the tech companies, which is, you know, a story unto itself.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Generally, companies want to hold onto the workers they have because it’s been very, very hard to hire.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you’ve got all these vacancies out there—far in excess of the number of employed people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That doesn’t sound like a—you know, a labor market where a lot of people will need to be put out of work.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that we—you know, there are channels through which the labor market can come back into balance with relatively modest increases in unemployment, we believe.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: None of that is guaranteed, but that is what their forecast reflects.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I haven’t made a judgment on what size rate hike to make at the last meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, you know, what you said is broadly right, which is, having moved so quickly and having now so much restraint that’s still in the pipeline, we think that the appropriate thing to do now is to move to a slower pace.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, that will allow us to feel our way and—you know, and get to that level, we think, and better balance the risks that we face.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s the idea.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It makes a lot of sense, it seems to me—particularly if you consider how far we’ve come.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, again, I can’t tell you today what the actual size of that will be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It will depend on a variety of factors, including the incoming data in particular, the state of the economy, the state of financial conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: No.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Absolutely not.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: No.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As a—just a matter of practice, the SEP reflects any data that’s—that comes out during the meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And participants know that they have the—they know this—that they can make changes to their SEP during the meeting, you know, well in advance of the press conference so that we’re not running around.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But that’s not the case.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s never the case that the SEPs don’t reflect an important piece of data that came in on the first day of the meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: No.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s not about the strength of the labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The labor market is clearly very strong.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It is more just that, you know, by now, we had expected—we’ve continually expected to make faster progress on inflation than we have, ultimately.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s why the peak rate for this year goes up between this meeting and the September meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You see that—you see the fact that we’ve made less progress than expected on inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s why that goes up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s why unemployment goes up, because we’re having to tighten policy more.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so it didn’t go up by much in the meeting, I don’t think.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But that’s the idea, is slower progress on inflation, tighter policy, probably higher rates probably held for longer just to get to where you—the kind of restriction that you need to get inflation down to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s very hard to say.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And history would, you know, would say that, in a situation like this, the declines in unemployment would be more meaningful, I think, than what you see written down there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, I’ll give you a few reasons.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: First just is that there’s this huge overhang of vacancies, meaning that vacancies can come down a fair amount.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re hearing from many companies that they don’t want to lay people off—so that they’ll keep people because it’s been so hard.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, I think we’ve—it feels like we have a structural labor shortage out there where there are, you know, 4 million fewer people, a little more than 4 million who were in the December 14, 2022 workforce available to work than there’s demand for workforce.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the fact that there’s a strong Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL labor market, you know, means that companies will hold on to workers.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it means that it may take longer, but it also means that the costs in unemployment may be less.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Again, that we’re going to find out empirically.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I think that’s a reasonably possible outcome.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you do hear, you know, many, many labor economists believe that it is.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’ll see, though.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, I think that’s why one of the reasons it went up was that core came in stronger this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yeah.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What you see is our best estimate, as of today—really, as of today—for how high we need to raise rates to—how much we need to tighten policy to create enough, you know, restrictive policy to slow economic activity and slow—soften the labor market and bring inflation down through those channels.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s all—that is the estimate—best estimate—we make today.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, as I mentioned, we’ll make another estimate for the next SEP. And we’ll, you know, of course, between meetings, we do the same thing, but we don’t publish it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re actually moving down to—the level that we’re moving down to next year is still a very large drop in inflation from where inflation is running now, well more than 1 percent change in inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But remember that the jump[ing]-off point at the beginning of the year is higher.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, we—we’re moving down still by a very large chunk.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t think it’s having—I don’t think the policy is having any less effect.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s just starting from a higher level at the end of 2022.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re getting down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I believe the median is 3½ percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That would be—that’s a pretty significant drop in inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s coming from the goods sector, clearly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: By the middle of next year, we should begin to see lower inflation from the housing services sector.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, that’s where you need to see—we believe you need to see a better balancing of supply and demand in the labor market so that you have—it’s not that we don’t want wage increases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We want strong wage increases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We just want them to be at a level that’s consistent with 2 percent inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Right now that—if you put into—if you factor in productivity estimates, standard productivity estimates, wages are running, you know, well above what would be consistent with 2 percent inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, our focus right now is really on moving our policy stance to one that is restrictive enough to ensure a return of inflation to our 2 percent goal over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s not on rate cuts.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we think that we’ll have to maintain a restrictive stance of policy for some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Historical experience cautions strongly against prematurely loosening policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I guess I would say it this way: I wouldn’t see us considering rate cuts until the Committee is confident that inflation is moving down to 2 percent in a sustained way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s the test I would articulate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you’re correct.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There are not rate cuts in the SEP for 2023.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you’re right.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Those two things will offset each other.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Weaker output in China will push down on commodity prices, but it could interfere with supply chains ultimately.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that could push inflation up in the West.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s very hard to say, you know, how much—how those two will offset each other.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it doesn’t seem likely, actually, that the overall net effect would be material on us.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, to your point, China faces a very challenging situation in reopening.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we’ve seen, waves of COVID all around the world can interfere with economic activity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: China, a very critical manufacturing—place for manufacturing December 14, 2022 and exporting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Their supply chain is very important.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And China faces a reopening.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They’ve— Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL you know, they’ve backed away from their COVID restriction policies.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There could be very significant increases in COVID.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ll just have to see.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s a risky situation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It—but, again, it doesn’t seem like it’s likely to have material overall effects on us.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Right.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the data that we’ve received so far for October and November, we don’t have the—some of the—we have some remaining data to get in November, but they clearly do show a welcome reduction in the monthly pace of price increases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I mentioned in my opening statement, it will take substantially more evidence to give confidence that inflation is on a sustained downward path.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the way we think about this is this: This report is very much in line with what we’ve been expecting and hoping for.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And what it does is, it provides greater confidence in our forecast of declining inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I mentioned, we’ve been expecting significant—forecasting significant declines in overall inflation and core inflation in the coming year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And this is the kind of reading that it will take to support that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, really, this gives us greater confidence in our forecasts rather than, at this point, changing our forecast.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of the pieces, we have been expecting goods inflation to come down as supply chain pressures eased.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s happening now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Housing services—as I December 14, 2022 mentioned, there’s good news in the pipeline.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As long as housing—new housing leases show Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL declining inflation, that will show up in the measure around the middle of next year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that should help.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the big piece, again, is core services, ex housing, which is very important.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we have a ways to go there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You do see some beginning signs there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, ultimately, that’s the big—the more than half, as I mentioned, of PCE core index.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s very fundamentally about the labor market and wages.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you look at wages, look at the average hourly earnings number we got with the last payrolls report, you don’t really see much progress in terms of average hourly earnings coming down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now, there may be composition effects and other effects in that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we don’t put too much weight on any one report.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These things can be volatile month to month.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we will be looking for wages moving, you know, down to more normal levels where workers are doing well and, ultimately, their gains are not being eaten up by inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So if I—I think I got your question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, one thing is to say is, I think our policy’s in—getting into a pretty good place now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re restrictive, and I think we’re—you know, we’re getting close to that level of sufficient—we think—sufficiently December 14, 2022 restrictive.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We laid out today what our best estimates are to get there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, of course, we’re—we welcome these better inflation reports for the last two months.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They’re very welcome.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I think we’re realistic about the broader project.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s all.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s the point I would make.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s—you know, we see goods prices coming down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We understand what will happen with housing services.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But the big story will really be the rest of it, and there’s not much progress there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s going to take some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think my view and my colleagues’ view is that this will take some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll have to hold policy at a restrictive level for a sustained period so that, you know, two good—you know, two good monthly reports are, you know, very welcome.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, they’re very welcome.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we need to be honest with ourselves that there’s, you know, inflation—12-month core inflation is 6 percent CPI.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s three times our 2 percent target.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now, it’s good to see progress.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But let’s just understand we have a long ways to go to get back to price stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: No, I wouldn’t say that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: No.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t say that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, I would say this: You know, to the extent we need to keep rates higher and keep them there for longer and inflation, you know, moves up higher and higher, I think that narrows the runway.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But lower inflation readings, if they persist, in time, could certainly make it more possible.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I just—I don’t think anyone knows whether we’re going to have a recession or not and, if we do, whether it’s going to be a deep one or not.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s just, it’s not knowable.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And certainly, you know, lower inflation reports, were they to continue for a period of time, would increase the likelihood of a—put it this way, of a return to price stability that involves significantly less of an increase in unemployment than would be expected given the historical record.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the largest amount of pain—the worst pain would come from a failure to raise rates high enough and from us allowing inflation to become entrenched in the economy so that the ultimate cost of getting it out of the economy would be very high in terms of employment, meaning very high unemployment for extended periods of time, the kind of thing that had to happen when inflation really got out of control and the Fed didn’t respond aggressively enough or soon enough in a prior episode, you know, 50 years ago.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s really—the worst pain would be if we failed to act.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What we’re doing now is, you know, it’s raising interest rates for people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so people are paying higher rates on mortgages and that kind of thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There will be some softening in labor market conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I wish there were a completely painless way to restore price stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There isn’t.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And this is the best we can do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I do think, though, that—and markets are pretty confident, it seems to me—that we will get inflation under control.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I believe we will.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re certainly highly committed to do that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s just—so, changing our inflation goal is just something we’re not thinking about, and it’s something we’re not going to think about.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s—we have a 2 percent inflation goal, and we’ll use our tools to get inflation back to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think this isn’t the time to be thinking about that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, there may be a longer-run project at some point.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But that is not where we are at all.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Committee—we’re not considering that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re not going to consider that under any circumstances.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re going to keep our inflation target at 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re going to use our tools to get inflation back to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the—I would go back to the labor market that we had in 2018, ’19, ’20.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, what that looked like was, wage increases for the people at the lowest end of the income spectrum were the largest.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The gaps between racial groups and gender groups were at their smallest in recorded history.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s—and all of that because of a tight labor market, a tight labor market which had inflation running, you know, just a tick below 2 percent and the economy growing right at its potential.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that seems like something that would be really good for the economy and for the country, if we could get back to that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so that’s what all of us want to do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We want to get back to a long expansion where the labor market can remain strong over an extended period of December 14, 2022 time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s a really good thing for workers in the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’d love to get back to that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL That’s what our goal is.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, there’s—in the near term, we have to use our tools to restore price stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we, you know, we can’t—what we have to think about is the medium and longer term.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you think about it, the country went through a difficult time—I think much more difficult than we can think it would happen here.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But it really set up our economy for several decades of prosperity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So price stability is something that really pays dividends for the benefit of the economy and the people in it over a very, very long period of time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so when it is lost, for whatever reason, it has to be restored and as quickly as possible—which is what we’re doing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We do, yes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We absolutely do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We look at—it’s our regular practice to talk about unemployment rates by different groups, including racial groups and that sort of thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We keep our eye on that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I don’t want to get into too many hypotheticals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, you know, we’ll—it’s hard to deal with hypotheticals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So let me just say that we have to use our tools to support maximum employment and price stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’ve made it clear that right now, the labor market’s very, very strong.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You’re near a 50-year low where you’re at or above maximum employment, a 50-year low in unemployment, vacancies are very high, wages—nominal wages December 14, 2022 are very high.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the labor market’s very, very strong.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Where we’re missing is on the inflation Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL side.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re missing by a lot on the inflation side.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that means we need to really focus on getting inflation under control, and that’s what we’ll do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think, as the economy heals, the two goals come more into play.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But right now, clearly, the focus has to be on getting inflation down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, what I meant by that, with “structural labor shortage,” is, if you look at where we are now, as I mentioned, there—if you just look at demand for labor, you can look at vacancies plus people who are actually working.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t see—despite very high wages and an incredibly tight labor market, we don’t see participation moving up—which is contrary to what we thought.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the upshot of all that is, the labor market is actually—it should—it’s 3½ million people, at least, smaller than it should have been based on pre-pandemic.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Just assume population and reasonable growth and aging of the population; our labor force should be 3½ million more than it is.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that—there’re lots of easy ways to get to bigger numbers than that if you go back a few more years.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Part of it is just accelerated retirements.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: People dropped out and aren’t coming back at a higher rate than expected.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Part of it is that we lost a half a million December 14, 2022 people who would have been work—close to half a million who would have been working died Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL from COVID.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And part of it is that migration has been lower.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t prescribe—you know, it’s not our job to prescribe things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, you know, I think if you ask businesses, you know, pretty much everybody you talk to says there aren’t enough people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We need more people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I tried to identify that in my—in a speech I gave a month ago, but I stopped short of telling Congress what to do because, you know, they gave us a job.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we need to, you know, do that job.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: No.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, what we do is, we make our forecasts, and we publish them quarterly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, if you look at those forecasts, those are forecasts for slow growth, for a softening labor market, by which I mean, unemployment goes up but not a great deal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you see inflation coming down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You see rates going up a lot.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You see inflation coming down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Those are those forecasts, and that’s really what they show.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re not—of course, we don’t talk about, you know, this kind of a recession and that kind of a recession.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We just, you know, we make those forecasts.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The staff runs—and you will see this if you look at the old Tealbooks—runs alternative simulations of all different kinds at every meeting, and we look at those, too.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And those will explore different things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But that’s just, you know, upside and downside scenarios.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, that’s a responsible practice that December 14, 2022 we’ve carried on for many decades.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, no, we don’t—we haven’t asked ourselves that Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we do know that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, that’s something that we know we’d see.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, as I mentioned, you know, we wouldn’t—I wouldn’t see the Committee cutting rates until we’re confident that inflation is moving down in a sustained way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That would be my test.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t see us as having a really clear and precise understanding of what the neutral rate is and what real rates are so that it would mechanically happen like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you very much.
